title: Banks should snoop on customers' spending habits to spot mental health issues, says charity
text:
Banks should be given greater power to use their customers’ data to identify people who may be struggling with their mental health, a leading think-tank has said.

An in-depth report released by the Money and Mental Health Policy Institute, a charity set up by moneysavingexpert.com founder Martin Lewis, recommended that banks should be able to monitor transactions and intervene in cases where they believe a customer is making poor financial decisions.

In many cases excessive or unusual spending patterns have been linked to mental health problems. Many people who have been diagnosed with a mental health issue also carry large debts thanks to overspending.
